docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''A Slave's Journey in Sudan,'' by Nicholas D. Kristof (column, April 23), refers to the ''school of thought within the Bush administration that we should not step into distant messes in which we have no compelling national interest at stake.'' The question is: How does this country define its national interests?
docs.abstract: Marea Siris Wexler letter on slavery in Sudan says US has not yet 'acknowledged or repaired' legacy of slavery in America (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, is engaged in discussions with the White House about how to expand health insurance coverage of mental illnesses, Congressional aides said tonight, but the negotiations have not produced any agreement. For several years, Mr. Domenici and Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, have been trying to enact legislation that would require employers to provide equivalent coverage, or parity, for mental and physical illnesses. But employers have strenuously resisted any new mandates, saying they would increase insurance costs, which are already rising rapidly.

headline.main: Officials Discuss Insurance for Mental Illness

docs.abstract: Sen Pete V Domenici is engaged in discussions with White House about how to expand health insurance coverage of mental illnesses, but negotiations have not produced any agreement; Washington Post says Pres Bush may announce his support for mental health parity at coming event in New Mexico, Domenici's home state (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 4,000 transit workers demonstrated in Midtown yesterday to pressure the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to contribute millions of dollars more to their health insurance plan. At an angry rally outside the authority's headquarters at Madison Avenue and 44th Street, leaders of the union representing 35,000 subway and bus workers warned that union members would have to pay more for health coverage unless the authority increased its contributions.

headline.main: 4,000 Press Transit Agency to Pay More for Health Coverage

docs.lead_paragraph: A study published today cast doubt on speculation that biological or genetic differences cause cancers to spread more aggressively in blacks than whites, leading to lower cancer survival rates. More likely, the report from Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York concluded, the well-documented disparity in survival rates between the races is caused by other factors, including coexisting medical conditions.

headline.main: Racial Gap in Cancer Survival Is Not Biological, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center study casts doubt on speculation that biological or genetic differences cause cancers to spread more aggressively in blacks than whites; concludes that well-docuented disparity in survival rates between the races is caused by other factors, including coexisting medical conditions; research is published in Journal of the American Medical Assn (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The union that represents 3,000 workers at Hershey Foods has given the company a 72-hour strike warning after failed negotiations and two rejected contract offers. The deadline was set for 9 a.m. Friday, if Wednesday's contract talks with a federal mediator fail.
docs.abstract: Chocolate Workers Local 464, which represents 3,000 workers at Hershey Foods, gives company 72-hour strike warning after failed negotiations and two rejected contract offers (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Reopening the Fresh Kills landfill would save the city $179.5 million next year. Eliminating paid sabbaticals for school teachers would save $74 million. Raising the income tax rate on the wealthiest citizens by one percentage point would net $563 million. Those ideas may not be popular with Staten Islanders, or teachers, or millionaires. And they are not in the budget plans of either the mayor or the City Council as they struggle to close a nearly $5 billion deficit for the year beginning July 1.

headline.main: Where Can City Find Revenue? Office Turns Over a Few Stones

docs.abstract: New York City's Independent Budget Office issues report Budget Options for New York; report analyzes variety of budget proposals, including many that would be politically difficult (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The growth in income inequality over the last several decades was particularly pronounced in a handful of states, including New York and California, while the gap between rich and poor narrowed in only one, Alaska, a report released today by two liberal research groups found. Using Census Bureau data, the two groups, the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities and the Economic Policy Institute, looked at household incomes at the peak of each of the last three economic cycles -- in the late 1970's, the late 80's and the late 90's -- and found that gains in the top 20 percent of families during those periods outstripped those in the bottom 20 percent in 44 states.

headline.main: Income Gap Widens Between Rich and Poor in 5 States and Narrows in 1

docs.abstract: Report using census data finds growth in income inequality over last several decades, with gains in top 20 percent of families outstripping those in bottom 20 percent in 44 states; gap between rich and poor was particularly pronounced in handful of states, including New York; chart of income gap (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of indirect victims of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center are struggling to obtain services because of narrowly drawn eligibility requirements for federal money and for the charities set up after Sept. 11, according to a study to be released today by the United Way of New York City. These victims, who lost livelihoods rather than loved ones as a result of the attack, even though they did not work in the immediate area, fail to qualify for help and are losing homes, health insurance and peace of mind, the study says. This has put further strains on the city's nonprofit service providers.

headline.main: Narrowly Drawn Rules Freeze Out Tens of Thousands of Indirect Victims, Report Says

docs.abstract: United Way of New York City study finds that tens of thousands of indirect victims of terrorist attack on World Trade Center are struggling to obtain services because of narrowly drawn eligibility requirements for federal money and for charities set up after Sept 11; finds that those who lost livelihoods rather than loved ones as result of attack, even though they do not work in immediate area, fail to qualify for help and are losing homes, health insurance and peace of mind; says this puts further strains on city's nonprofit service providers; says ripple effect on economy extends far beyond Canal Street; charities are being cautious about way they disburse funds earmarked for Sept 11 victims following fuss made about American Red Cross practice of holding back some Sept 11 donations in reserve fund for future disasters (M)
